Chief Complaint: Chief Complaint:Respiratory Distress
   .
   Reason for MICU admission: Hypoxia, tachypnea
   24 Hour Events:
   [**2189-1-23**]
   - Echo report: IMPRESSION: Moderately dilated and mildly hypokinetic
   right ventricle. Moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation. Severe
   pulmonary hypertension. Preserved left ventricular global systolic
   function. Elevated estimated filling pressures.
   - Pt with persistent hypoglycemia not responsive to juice and dextrose.
   Checked TSH and random [**Last Name (un) **] which were wnl
   - Pt was negative 2L by MN
   - PM lytes stable
   - Pt became very agitated, screaming, crying, pulled out tele, IV line,
   was given haldol 2mg IM ONCE which calmed her down for 2 hours.
   -Cooperated with receiving a second IV, got agitated again and received
   another dose of haldol at 1am
   -Again agitated, at 2:30am, received 4mg haldol
   -Also zyprexa increased to 5mg [**Hospital1 **] and recieved 5mg additional zyprexa
   at night
   -QTC on 12 lead was 460 after all these doses
   - Increased zyprexa from 2.5mg PO BID to 5mg PO BID

   [**2189-1-23**] CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
   FINDINGS: In comparison with the study of [**1-22**], the patient has taken a
   somewhat better inspiration. There is little overall change in the
   cardiomegaly with elevated pulmonary venous pressure and right-sided
   effusion and post-surgical changes in the right upper lobe.
   [**2189-1-23**] ECHO:
   The left atrium is elongated. The right atrium is markedly dilated.
   Left ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. Due to
   suboptimal technical quality, a focal wall motion abnormality cannot be
   fully excluded. Overall left ventricular systolic function is low
   normal (LVEF 50-55%). The estimated cardiac index is normal
   (>=2.5L/min/m2). Tissue Doppler imaging suggests an increased left
   ventricular filling pressure (PCWP>18mmHg). The right ventricular
   cavity is moderately dilated with mild global free wall hypokinesis.
   [Intrinsic right ventricular systolic function is likely more depressed
   given the severity of tricuspid regurgitation.] There is abnormal
   septal motion/position consistent with right ventricular
   pressure/volume overload. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly
   thickened. There is a minimally increased gradient consistent with
   minimal aortic valve stenosis. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The
   mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve
   prolapse. Moderate to severe [3+] tricuspid regurgitation is seen.
   There is severe pulmonary artery systolic hypertension.
   IMPRESSION: Moderately dilated and mildly hypokinetic right ventricle.
   Moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation. Severe pulmonary
   hypertension. Preserved left ventricular global systolic function.
   Elevated estimated filling pressures.

   Assessment and Plan
 CANCER (MALIGNANT NEOPLASM), BREAST
 HYPOXEMIA
 DEPRESSION
 DELIRIUM / CONFUSION
 HYPERTENSION, BENIGN
 HYPOGLYCEMIA
   78 yo F with h/o COPD, lung ca s/p lobectomy, breast CA s/p lumpectomy
   who presents with altered mental status and new hypercarbic/hypoxic
   respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic/Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Multiple possible etiologies
   including moderate right pleural effusion, bilateral opacities and
   elevated WBC raising suspicion for infectious process, total body
   overload and cardiomegaly concerning for acute heart failure. Give
   tachycardia and hypoxia, PE also a possibility. Also consider less
   likely causes such as malginancy to account for effusion and bilateral
   opacities. Hypoglycemic episodes likely contributing to episode of
   hypercarbia. No e/o acute MI, likely had a small troponin leak related
   to demand ischemia. BNP supports acute CHF but I suspect she is
   dehydrated now and still hypoxic and tachycardic despite diuresis
   - Hold on diuresis
   - standing ipratropium nebs Q6H, albuterol Q2H prn SOB, wheezing,
   tachypnea
   - continue vanc/cefepime for empiric coverage of HCAP
   - f/u urine cultures
   - Pt
s healthcare proxy refusing thoracentesis
   - D/w healthcare proxy if CTA chest would be in line with pt
s goals of
   care to r/o PE given evidence of right sided strain on echo and now
   persistent tachycardia and hypoxia
   - work up concern for malignancy as below
   - wean O2, still hypoxic at present
   .
   # Hypoglycemia/Type II DM with complications
 Improving. Was on lantus
   70units at NH, last does >24 hours prior to admission to ICU and
   remains hypoglycemic to 60s. Unclear if there has been a recent med
   change. Question if related to infectious process, NPO, insulin
   producing malignancy. No acute renal failure to explain decrease
   insulint requirement.
   - hold long acting insulin for now, cover with humalog sliding scale
   .
   # Right Breast Mass and skin changes - concerning for inflammatory
   breast ca vs breast CA relapse. Did have right cyst on [**Last Name (un) **] from [**5-13**]
   with plan for 6 month f/u given comorbidities
   - once stable obtain diagnostic mammography
   .
   # Abdominal Distention - Patient complaining of increasing abdominal
   girth x2 months. Abdominal U/S c/w small pocket of ascites possibly
   related to heart failure.
   - AB US to eval for ascites
   - check LFTs
 wnl except for AP and LDH
   - Monitor for worsening.
   - Invasive work up likely inconsistent with patient
s goals of care
   .
   # Delirium on dementia/Depression/Anxiety: Appears to be an acute
   change prompting presentation to ED in setting of progressive decline
   over the past two months, most notably over the past two weeks.
   Etiology likely toxic metabolic. Does have intermittent SI.
   - Will continue antibiotics, treatment as above for repiratory failure
   - Psychiatry recs
   - Haldol PRN
   - Daily EKGs to monitor QTc
   - Continue outpatient regiment pending psychiatry recommendations
   - hold QHS benzo given delirium,
   - increase olanzapine from 2.5gm PO BID to 5mg PO BID
    .
   # Hypertension:
   - switch long acting Dilt to short acting
   - resume Lisinopril once stablizes
   .
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, can eat now that respiratory
   status improved
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   .
   # Access: peripherals
   .
   # Code:  DNR/DNI -confirmed with pt and HCP
   .
   # Communication: Patient and HCP
   .
   # Disposition: pending clinical improvement
   .
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: NPO pending respiratory improvement
   Glycemic Control: Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2189-1-23**] 08:40 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: not necessary
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication: Patient discussed on interdisciplinary rounds  Comments:
   Code status: DNR / DNI
   Disposition: ICU

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the information as follows:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of COPD, lung cancer, and breast cancer, who presents with altered mental status and new hypercarbic/hypoxic respiratory failure. She has a moderate right pleural effusion, bilateral opacities, and elevated WBC, raising suspicion for an infectious process. She also has cardiomegaly, concerning for acute heart failure, and has been treated with diuresis.

The patient has been experiencing hypoglycemic episodes, which are likely contributing to her hypercarbia. She has been treated with antibiotics for empiric coverage of hospital-acquired pneumonia, and her urine cultures are pending. She has also been treated with inhalers for respiratory failure.

The patient has a right breast mass and skin changes, which are concerning for inflammatory breast cancer or breast cancer relapse. She has a small pocket of ascites, possibly related to heart failure, and her abdominal ultrasound is pending. She has also been experiencing abdominal distension, which is being monitored.

The patient has a history of depression, anxiety, and dementia, and is currently experiencing delirium. She has been treated with antipsychotics and antidepressants, and her psychiatric treatment plan is pending.

The patient has hypertension, which is being treated with medications. She has also been experiencing hypoxia, which is being treated with oxygen therapy.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen, leading to further hypoxia and hypercarbia.
2. Infections: The patient's elevated WBC and bilateral opacities raise suspicion for an infectious process, which can worsen her condition.
3. Heart failure: The patient's cardiomegaly and elevated filling pressures suggest acute heart failure, which can worsen her condition.
4. Malignancy: The patient's right breast mass and skin changes are concerning for inflammatory breast cancer or breast cancer relapse, which can worsen her condition.
5. Delirium: The patient's delirium can worsen, leading to further cognitive impairment and increased risk of falls and other complications.
6. Hypoglycemia: The patient's hypoglycemic episodes can worsen, leading to further hypercarbia and respiratory failure.
7. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension can worsen, leading to further cardiovascular complications.

Based on the patient's condition, I recommend the following:

1. Continue respiratory therapy to improve her oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Continue antibiotics for empiric coverage of hospital-acquired pneumonia.
3. Monitor her respiratory status closely and adjust her treatment plan as needed.
4. Consider further diagnostic testing, such as a chest CT scan, to rule out PE and other complications.
5. Continue antipsychotics and antidepressants to manage her delirium and depression.
6. Monitor her glycemic control closely and adjust her insulin regimen as needed.
7. Continue to manage her hypertension and cardiovascular risk factors.
8. Consider further evaluation and treatment for her right breast mass and skin changes.
9. Monitor her abdominal distension and ascites closely and adjust her treatment plan as needed.
10. Consider further evaluation and treatment for her delirium and cognitive impairment.

   78 yo F with h/o COPD, lung ca s/p lobectomy, breast CA s/p lumpectomy
   who presents with altered mental status and new hypercarbic/hypoxic
   respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic/Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Multiple possible etiologies
   including moderate right pleural effusion, bilateral opacities and
   elevated WBC raising suspicion for infectious process, total body
   overload and cardiomegaly concerning for acute heart failure. Give
   tachycardia and hypoxia, PE also a possibility. Also consider less
   likely causes such as malginancy to account for effusion and bilateral
   opacities. Hypoglycemic episodes likely contributing to episode of
   hypercarbia. No e/o acute MI, likely had a small troponin leak related
   to demand ischemia. BNP supports acute CHF. I suspect she is dried out
   now.
   - Hold on diuresis
   - standing ipratropium nebs Q6H, albuterol Q2H prn SOB, wheezing,
   tachypnea
   - continue vanc/cefepime for empiric coverage of HCAP
   - f/u urine cultures
   - consider right throacentesis for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes
   - Likely CTA chest to r/o PE given evidence of right sided strain on
   echo and now persistent tachycardia and hypoxia
   - work up concern for malignancy as below
   - wean O2, still hypoxic at present
   .
   # Hypoglycemia/Type II DM with complications
 Improving. Was on lantus
   70units at NH, last does >24 hours prior to admission to ICU and
   remains hypoglycemic to 60s. Unclear if there has been a recent med
   change. Question if related to infectious process, NPO, insulin
   producing malignancy. No acute renal failure to explain decrease
   insulint requirement.
   - hold long acting insulin for now, cover with humalog sliding scale
   .
   # Right Breast Mass and skin changes - concerning for inflammatory
   breast ca vs breast CA relapse. Did have right cyst on [**Last Name (un) **] from [**5-13**]
   with plan for 6 month f/u given comorbidities
   - once stable obtain diagnostic mammography
   .
   # Abdominal Distention - Patient complaining of increasing abdominal
   girth x2 months. Abdominal U/S c/w ascites.
   - AB US to eval for ascites
   - check LFTs
 wnl except for AP and LDH
   - Trend
   .
   # Delirium on dementia/Depression/Anxiety: Appears to be an acute
   change prompting presentation to ED in setting of progressive decline
   over the past two months, most notably over the past two weeks.
   Etiology likely toxic metabolic. Does have intermittent SI.
   - Will continue antibiotics, treatment as above for repiratory failure
   - Psychiatry recs
   - Haldol PRN
   - Daily EKGs to monitor QTc
   - Continue outpatient regiment pending Psychiatry recommendations
   - hold QHS benzo given delirium,
   - increase QHS olanzapine prn agitation
    .
   # Hypertension:
   - switch long acting Dilt to short acting
   - resume Lisinopril once stablizes
   .
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, can eat now that respiratory
   status improved
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   .
   # Access: peripherals
   .
   # Code:  DNR/DNI -confirmed with pt and HCP
   .
   # Communication: Patient and HCP
   .
   # Disposition: pending clinical improvement
   .
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: NPO pending respiratory improvement
   Glycemic Control: Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2189-1-23**] 08:40 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: not necessary
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication: Patient discussed on interdisciplinary rounds  Comments:
   Code status: DNR / DNI
   Disposition: ICU

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following key points:

1. Respiratory Distress: The patient is experiencing hypoxia, tachypnea, and hypercarbic respiratory failure, with a possible etiology including moderate right pleural effusion, bilateral opacities, and elevated WBC, raising suspicion for an infectious process.
2. Cardiac Issues: The patient has a history of lung cancer and breast cancer, and the echocardiogram shows a moderately dilated and mildly hypokinetic right ventricle, moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation, and severe pulmonary hypertension. The estimated cardiac index is normal, but the patient has a low-normal left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF 50-55%).
3. Hypoglycemia: The patient has a history of type II diabetes and was on Lantus insulin, but remains hypoglycemic despite being NPO for over 24 hours. The patient's insulin requirements may have decreased due to an infectious process, NPO, or an insulin-producing malignancy.
4. Abdominal Distention: The patient has a history of increasing abdominal girth over two months, and an abdominal ultrasound shows a small pocket of ascites in the right lower quadrant.
5. Delirium: The patient is experiencing delirium, likely due to a toxic metabolic cause, and has a history of depression, dementia, and anxiety.
6. Hypertension: The patient has hypertension, which is being managed with medication.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen, leading to further hypoxia, hypercarbia, and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac issues, including pulmonary hypertension and tricuspid regurgitation, can lead to further cardiac decompensation, including heart failure and arrhythmias.
3. Infection: The patient's elevated WBC and suspicion of an infectious process can lead to sepsis, organ dysfunction, and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Malignancy: The patient's history of breast cancer and lung cancer can lead to further complications, including metastasis and recurrence.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient's hypoglycemia can worsen, leading to further complications, including seizures, coma, and potentially life-threatening consequences.
6. Delirium: The patient's delirium can worsen, leading to further complications, including increased agitation, aggression, and potentially life-threatening consequences.

To address these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored for respiratory failure, cardiac complications, infection, and malignancy. The patient's hypoglycemia should be managed with a sliding scale of insulin, and the patient's delirium should be managed with a combination of medications and behavioral interventions. The patient's hypertension should be managed with medication and lifestyle modifications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old female admitted to the MICU with respiratory distress, hypoxia, and tachypnea. The patient has a history of breast cancer and is currently experiencing hypoglycemia, which is not responsive to juice and dextrose.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.5F (36.9C), heart rate of 94 bpm, and blood pressure of 132/85 mmHg. The patient is receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula and has a SpO2 of 96%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating potential cardiac injury. The echocardiogram reveals a moderately dilated and mildly hypokinetic right ventricle, moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation, and severe pulmonary hypertension. The patient also has a small pocket of ascites in the right lower quadrant.

The patient's respiratory support includes oxygen therapy via nasal cannula, and the patient is receiving haldol for agitation. The patient's electrolytes are stable, with a potassium level of 4.2 mEq/L and a magnesium level of 2.1 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia and tachypnea may lead to respiratory failure if not adequately managed.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's echocardiogram results suggest potential cardiac injury, and the patient's cardiac index is normal but may be more depressed given the severity of tricuspid regurgitation.
3. Hypoglycemia: The patient's persistent hypoglycemia may lead to further complications if not adequately managed.
4. Delirium: The patient's agitation and delirium may worsen if not managed with appropriate sedation and therapy.
5. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's immobility and underlying medical conditions may increase the risk of DVT.
6. Stress ulcer: The patient's critical illness and underlying medical conditions may increase the risk of stress ulcer.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory status, and to adjust therapy accordingly to prevent potential complications.

 DELIRIUM / CONFUSION

   78 yo F with h/o COPD, lung ca s/p lobectomy, breast CA s/p lumpectomy
   who presents with altered mental status and new hypercarbic/hypoxic
   respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic/Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Multiple possible etiologies
   including moderate right pleural effusion, bilateral opacities and
   elevated WBC raising suspicion for infectious process, total body
   overload and cardiomegaly concerning for acute heart failure. Give
   tachycardia and hypoxia, PE also a possibility. Also consider less
   likely causes such as malginancy to account for effusion and bilateral
   opacities. Hypoglycemic episodes likely contributing to episode of
   hypercarbia. No e/o acute MI, likely had a small troponin leak related
   to demand ischemia. BNP supports acute CHF but I suspect she is total
   volume up but intravascularly deplete given ARF and elevated bicarb.
   - Continue diuresis more gently, goal negative of 500cc with smaller
   lasix boluses, if cr unable to tolerate consider small lasix gtt
   - standing ipratropium nebs Q6H, albuterol Q2H prn SOB, wheezing,
   tachypnea
   - continue vanc/cefepime for empiric coverage of HCAP for 8 day course
   (start date [**2189-1-23**])
   - f/u urine cultures, no blood cx drawn
   - Pt
s healthcare proxy refusing thoracentesis
   - CTA chest to r/o PE given evidence of right sided strain on echo and
   now persistent tachycardia and hypoxia
   - attempt to wean O2, though still hypoxic at present
   .
   # Hypoglycemia/Type II DM with complications
 Improving. Was on lantus
   70units at NH, last does >24 hours prior to admission to ICU and
   remains hypoglycemic to 60s. Unclear if there has been a recent med
   change. Question if related to infectious process, NPO, insulin
   producing malignancy. No acute renal failure to explain decrease
   insulint requirement.
   - hold long acting insulin for now, cover with humalog sliding scale
   .
   # Right Breast Mass and skin changes - concerning for inflammatory
   breast ca vs breast CA relapse. Did have right cyst on [**Last Name (un) **] from [**5-13**]
   with plan for 6 month f/u given comorbidities
   - once stable obtain diagnostic mammography
   .
   # Abdominal Distention - Patient complaining of increasing abdominal
   girth x2 months. Abdominal U/S c/w small pocket of ascites possibly
   related to heart failure.
   - AB US to eval for ascites
   - check LFTs
 wnl except for AP and LDH
   - Monitor for worsening.
   - Invasive work up inconsistent with patient
s goals of care
   .
   # Delirium on dementia/Depression/Anxiety: Pt with significant
   sundowning last night.  Appears to be an acute change prompting
   presentation to ED in setting of progressive decline over the past two
   months, most notably over the past two weeks. Etiology likely toxic
   metabolic. Does have intermittent SI.
   - Obtain CT head
   - Will continue antibiotics, treatment as above for repiratory failure
   - Talk with psychiatry re better strategy to manage sundowning
   - Haldol PRN
   - Daily EKGs to monitor QTc
   - Continue outpatient regiment pending psychiatry recommendations
   - hold QHS benzo given delirium,
   - increase olanzapine from 2.5gm PO BID to 5mg PO BID
    .
   # Hypertension:
   - switch long acting Dilt to short acting
   - hold Lisinopril given ARF
   # ARF: likely from intravascular volume depletion from lasix, supported
   by BUN/cr ratio
   - Back off on intensity of diuresis
   .
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, can eat now that respiratory
   status improved
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   .
   # Access: peripherals
   .
   # Code:  DNR/DNI -confirmed with pt and HCP
   .
   # Communication: Patient and HCP
   .
   # Disposition: pending clinical improvement
   .
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: Diabetic/cardiac healthy diet
   Glycemic Control: Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2189-1-23**] 08:40 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: not necessary
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication: Patient and patient
s HCP [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11092**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11093**]
   Code status: DNR / DNI
   Disposition: ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of COPD, lung cancer, and breast cancer, currently admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress, hypoxia, and tachypnea. She has a moderate right pleural effusion, bilateral opacities, and elevated WBC, raising suspicion for an infectious process. She also has cardiomegaly, acute heart failure, and severe pulmonary hypertension. The patient has been experiencing hypoglycemic episodes, and her blood glucose levels have been uncontrolled. She has also been experiencing delirium, sundowning, and depression.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and hypoxia are concerning, and she may require mechanical ventilation.
2. Infection: The patient's elevated WBC and bilateral opacities suggest an infectious process, which may require antibiotic therapy.
3. Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiomegaly and acute heart failure may require diuretic therapy and other treatments.
4. Hypoglycemia: The patient's uncontrolled blood glucose levels may require insulin therapy and close monitoring.
5. Delirium: The patient's delirium and sundowning may require treatment with antipsychotics and other medications.
6. Depression: The patient's depression may require treatment with antidepressants and other therapies.
7. Right breast mass: The patient's right breast mass may require further evaluation and treatment.
8. Abdominal distension: The patient's abdominal distension may require further evaluation and treatment.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is complex, and she requires close monitoring and treatment. The plan includes:

1. Continue diuresis with gentle lasix boluses and monitor for signs of volume depletion.
2. Continue antibiotic therapy for empiric coverage of HCAP.
3. Obtain CTA chest to rule out PE.
4. Attempt to wean O2, but still hypoxic.
5. Hold long-acting insulin and cover with humalog sliding scale.
6. Obtain diagnostic mammography for right breast mass.
7. Monitor for worsening abdominal distension.
8. Continue antibiotics and treatment for respiratory failure.
9. Obtain CT head to evaluate delirium.
10. Continue outpatient regimen pending psychiatry recommendations.
11. Hold QHS benzo and increase olanzapine from 2.5mg PO BID to 5mg PO BID.
12. Switch long-acting Dilt to short-acting and hold Lisinopril due to ARF.
13. Back off on intensity of diuresis due to ARF.
14. Replete electrolytes and monitor for signs of volume depletion.
15. Continue prophylactic subcutaneous heparin.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

   78 yo F with h/o COPD, lung ca s/p lobectomy, breast CA s/p lumpectomy
   who presents with altered mental status and new hypercarbic/hypoxic
   respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic/Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: CXR w/ opacities and
   leukocytosis on admission, suspicion for infectious process.  Echo also
   notable for moderate pulmonary hypertension with RHF.  No evidence of
   PE on echo. No e/o acute MI, likely had a small troponin leak related
   to demand ischemia.
   - Hold diuresis given elevated Cr
   - Cont nebs
   - Cont vanc/cefepime for empiric coverage of HCAP for 8 day course
   (start date [**2189-1-23**])
   - F/u final read CTA
   - Wean O2 (on 2L nc at home)
   .
   # CHF: Echo w/ RHF and pulm HTN, and evidence of ascites on abdominal
   US. left sided/diastolic failure
   - holding ace-I given elevated Cr
   - continue statin
   - hold further diuresis w/ lasix
   .
   # Hypoglycemia/Type II DM with complications
 Improving. Was on lantus
   70units at NH.
   - hold long acting insulin for now, cover with humalog sliding scale
   .
   # Right Breast Mass and skin changes - concerning for inflammatory
   breast ca vs breast CA relapse. Did have right cyst on [**Last Name (un) **] from [**5-13**]
   with plan for 6 month f/u given comorbidities
   - once stable obtain diagnostic mammography
   .
   # Abdominal Distention
 Ab US w/ evidence of ascites likely related to
   HF in the absence of transaminitis.
   - Monitor for worsening.
   .
   # Delirium on dementia/Depression/Anxiety: Pt with significant
   sundowning last night.  Delirium likely toxic metabolic, infectious.
   Does have intermittent SI. CT head w/o acute process
   - Continue antibiotics for pna
   - Haldol PRN
   - Daily EKGs to monitor QTc
   - Cont increased olanzapine 5mg PO BID
   - Holding ativan and avoiding benzos/anticholinergics
    .
   # Hypertension:
   - cont dilt
   - hold Lisinopril given ARF
   - cont asa
   # ARF: likely from intravascular volume depletion from lasix. Also
   received contrast for CTA
   - Hold lasix
   - IVFs
   - mucomyst
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of COPD, lung cancer, and breast cancer, who presents with altered mental status, new hypercarbic/hypoxic respiratory failure, and acute kidney injury. She has a large right pleural effusion, small left pleural effusion, and dense material in the consolidated/collapsed right lower lobe, which may be related to aspiration or pneumonia. She has a history of hypertension, hypoglycemia, and depression.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4C, heart rate of 95 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 128/94 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 25 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 100% on nasal cannula. She has a small right effusion and increased streaky density at the right base consistent with subsegmental atelectasis on chest X-ray.

Laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, elevated blood urea nitrogen, and elevated creatinine. Urine culture shows gram-positive bacteria, consistent with alpha-streptococcus or lactobacillus sp.

The patient's condition is complex, with multiple potential medical complications. She has:

1. Hypercarbic/hypoxic respiratory failure, which may be related to pneumonia or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
2. Acute kidney injury, which may be related to intravascular volume depletion, contrast-induced nephropathy, or other causes.
3. Hypertension, which may be related to chronic kidney disease, medication use, or other causes.
4. Hypoglycemia, which may be related to diabetes or other causes.
5. Depression, which may be related to her underlying medical conditions or other factors.
6. Right breast mass and skin changes, which may be related to inflammatory breast cancer or breast cancer relapse.
7. Abdominal distension, which may be related to heart failure or other causes.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure, which may require mechanical ventilation.
2. Kidney failure, which may require dialysis.
3. Cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
4. Infections, such as pneumonia or sepsis.
5. Neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke.
6. Gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or obstruction.
7. Endocrine complications, such as hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.

Given the patient's complex medical condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management in the ICU.

Based on the patient's 24-hour progress note, the following information is summarized:

The patient is a 60-inch tall, 78.8 kg individual with a history of breast cancer, hypertension, and hypoglycemia. They are currently in the ICU with a diagnosis of pneumonia, respiratory distress, and sepsis. The patient has been experiencing respiratory distress, pulling off their mask, and desaturating to the 70s, which improved with nebulizers. They also had an episode of agitation, pulling out their foley catheter, and had a small pleural effusion on the right side.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4C, heart rate of 95 bpm, blood pressure of 128/94 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute. They are receiving oxygen therapy through a nasal cannula and have a SpO2 of 100%.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and creatinine level. Their troponin-T level is elevated at 0.09 ng/mL, indicating possible cardiac damage. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level.

The patient's imaging studies show a large right pleural effusion, small left pleural effusion, and dense material in the consolidated/collapsed right lower lobe, which may be due to aspiration or pneumonia. The patient's echocardiogram shows moderately dilated and mildly hypokinetic right ventricle, moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation, and severe pulmonary hypertension.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Pneumonia-related respiratory failure
2. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction
3. Cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure, due to the elevated troponin-T level
4. Respiratory distress syndrome
5. Pleural effusion-related respiratory compromise
6. Infection-related electrolyte imbalance
7. Hypoglycemia-related neurologic complications

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan of care is recommended:

1. Continue oxygen therapy and monitor for signs of respiratory distress.
2. Administer antibiotics for the suspected pneumonia and sepsis.
3. Monitor for signs of cardiac complications and consider cardiac consultation.
4. Monitor for signs of respiratory failure and consider intubation if necessary.
5. Monitor for signs of pleural effusion-related respiratory compromise and consider drainage if necessary.
6. Monitor for signs of infection-related electrolyte imbalance and adjust treatment accordingly.
7. Monitor for signs of hypoglycemia-related neurologic complications and adjust treatment accordingly.

 CANCER (MALIGNANT NEOPLASM), BREAST

 DELIRIUM / CONFUSION
 HYPERTENSION, BENIGN
 HYPOGLYCEMIA
   78 yo F with h/o COPD, lung ca s/p lobectomy, breast CA s/p lumpectomy
   who presents with altered mental status and new hypercarbic/hypoxic
   respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic/Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Multifactorial, CXR w/
   opacities and leukocytosis on admission, suspicion for infectious
   process.  Echo also notable for moderate pulmonary hypertension with
   RHF.  No evidence of PE on echo. Also consider less likely causes such
   as malginancy to account for effusion and bilateral opacities.
   Hypoglycemic episodes likely contributing to episode of hypercarbia. No
   e/o acute MI, likely had a small troponin leak related to demand
   ischemia.
   - Continue diuresis more gently, goal negative of 500cc with smaller
   lasix boluses, if cr unable to tolerate consider small lasix gtt
   - standing ipratropium nebs Q6H, albuterol Q2H prn SOB, wheezing,
   tachypnea
   - continue vanc/cefepime for empiric coverage of HCAP for 8 day course
   (start date [**2189-1-23**])
   - f/u urine cultures, no blood cx drawn
   - Pt
s healthcare proxy refusing thoracentesis
   - F/u final read CTA
   - Wean O2
   .
   # RHF: Echo w/ RHF and pulm HTN, and evidence of ascites on abdominal
   US.
   - bb
   - ace-i
   - statin
   - lasix
   .
   # Hypoglycemia/Type II DM with complications
 Improving. Was on lantus
   70units at NH, last does >24 hours prior to admission to ICU and
   remains hypoglycemic to 60s. Unclear if there has been a recent med
   change. Question if related to infectious process, NPO, insulin
   producing malignancy.
   - hold long acting insulin for now, cover with humalog sliding scale
   .
   # Right Breast Mass and skin changes - concerning for inflammatory
   breast ca vs breast CA relapse. Did have right cyst on [**Last Name (un) **] from [**5-13**]
   with plan for 6 month f/u given comorbidities
   - once stable obtain diagnostic mammography
   .
   # Abdominal Distention
 Ab US w/ evidence of ascites likely related to
   HF in the absence of transaminitis.
   - Monitor for worsening.
   - Invasive work up inconsistent with patient
s goals of care
   .
   # Delirium on dementia/Depression/Anxiety: Pt with significant
   sundowning last night.  Appears to be an acute change prompting
   presentation to ED in setting of progressive decline over the past two
   months, most notably over the past two weeks. Etiology likely toxic
   metabolic. Does have intermittent SI.
   - Obtain CT head
   - Will continue antibiotics, treatment as above for repiratory failure
   - Talk with psychiatry re better strategy to manage sundowning
   - Haldol PRN
   - Daily EKGs to monitor QTc
   - Continue outpatient regiment pending psychiatry recommendations
   - hold QHS benzo given delirium,
   - increase olanzapine from 2.5gm PO BID to 5mg PO BID
    .
   # Hypertension:
   - switch long acting Dilt to short acting
   - hold Lisinopril given ARF
   # ARF: likely from intravascular volume depletion from lasix, supported
   by BUN/cr ratio
   - Back off on intensity of diuresis
   .
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, can eat now that respiratory
   status improved
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   .
   # Access: peripherals
   .
   # Code:  DNR/DNI -confirmed with pt and HCP
   .
   # Communication: Patient and HCP
   .
   # Disposition: pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2189-1-24**] 10:30 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: DNR / DNI
   Disposition:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), lung cancer, and breast cancer. She was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, new hypercarbic/hypoxic respiratory failure, and hypoglycemic episodes.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula, and her SpO2 is 100%. She has a history of respiratory failure, and her CXR shows pulmonary vascular congestion, small right effusion, and subsegmental atelectasis.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation, severe pulmonary hypertension, and a mildly hypokinetic right ventricle. She has a history of hypertension and is currently on antihypertensive medications.
* Neurological status: The patient is experiencing delirium, which is likely related to toxic metabolic changes. She has a history of depression, anxiety, and dementia.
* Renal status: The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) and is receiving diuretic therapy. Her creatinine levels are elevated, and she has a BUN/cr ratio indicating intravascular volume depletion.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has ascites, which is likely related to her heart failure. She has a history of liver disease and is receiving anticoagulant therapy.
* Infectious status: The patient has a positive urine culture for alpha-hemolytic bacteria, which is consistent with alpha-streptococcus or lactobacillus sp. She is receiving empiric antibiotics for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HCAP).
* Laboratory results: The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating cardiac injury. Her blood glucose levels are fluctuating, and she has a history of hypoglycemic episodes.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is fragile, and she may experience further decline in her respiratory function.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and she may experience further cardiac injury or arrhythmias.
* Renal complications: The patient's AKI may progress to chronic kidney disease, and she may require dialysis.
* Infectious complications: The patient is at risk for further infections, particularly in the respiratory and urinary tracts.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's ascites may worsen, and she may experience further gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Neurological complications: The patient's delirium may persist or worsen, and she may experience further cognitive decline.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple comorbidities and ongoing medical issues. She requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and improve her overall condition.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of COPD, lung cancer, and breast cancer. She is currently admitted to the ICU for hypercarbic/hypoxic respiratory failure, likely due to a multifactorial process including infectious causes, pulmonary hypertension, and right heart failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: She is on nasal cannula oxygen and has a SpO2 of 100%. Her respiratory rate is 25 breaths per minute, and her blood pressure is 128/94 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular: She has moderate pulmonary hypertension with right heart failure, as evidenced by her echocardiogram. Her blood pressure is 128/94 mmHg.
* Neurological: She has altered mental status, likely due to hypoxia, hypercarbia, and delirium. Her neurological examination is not assessed due to her altered mental status.
* Renal: She has acute kidney injury (AKI) with a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 39 mg/dL and a creatinine of 1.4 mg/dL.
* Hematological: She has a white blood cell count of 9.2 x 10^9/L and a platelet count of 220 x 10^9/L.
* Infectious: She has a urine culture positive for Gram-positive bacteria, likely alpha streptococcus or Lactobacillus sp.

The patient's medical history is significant for lung cancer, breast cancer, and type II diabetes. She has a history of COPD and has undergone a lobectomy and lumpectomy.

The potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen, leading to further hypoxia and hypercarbia.
* Sepsis: The patient's positive urine culture and altered mental status increase the risk of sepsis.
* Right heart failure: The patient's moderate pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure can worsen, leading to further cardiac compromise.
* AKI: The patient's AKI can worsen, leading to further renal dysfunction.
* Delirium: The patient's delirium can worsen, leading to further cognitive decline.
* Infections: The patient is at risk for further infections, particularly pneumonia and sepsis.
* Malignancy: The patient's breast cancer and lung cancer can worsen, leading to further metastasis and poor prognosis.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continue diuresis with smaller lasix boluses to reduce fluid overload.
* Continue antibiotics for empiric coverage of HCAP.
* Monitor for worsening respiratory failure and sepsis.
* Wean oxygen therapy as tolerated.
* Obtain diagnostic mammography to evaluate the patient's right breast mass.
* Continue outpatient regiment pending psychiatry recommendations to manage delirium and sundowning.
* Hold long-acting insulin and cover with humalog sliding scale.
* Monitor for worsening AKI and adjust diuretic therapy as needed.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and improve her clinical outcome.

   who presents with altered mental status and new hypercarbic/hypoxic
   respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic/Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: CXR w/ opacities and
   leukocytosis on admission, suspicion for infectious process.  Echo also
   notable for moderate pulmonary hypertension with RHF.  No evidence of
   PE on echo. No e/o acute MI, likely had a small troponin leak related
   to demand ischemia.
   - Hold diuresis given elevated Cr
   - Cont nebs
   - Cont vanc/cefepime for empiric coverage of HCAP for 8 day course
   (start date [**2189-1-23**])
   - F/u final read CTA
   - Wean O2 (on 2L nc at home)
   .
   # CHF: Echo w/ RHF and pulm HTN, and evidence of ascites on abdominal
   US. left sided/diastolic failure
   - holding ace-I given elevated Cr
   - continue statin
   - hold further diuresis w/ lasix
   .
   # Hypoglycemia/Type II DM with complications
 Improving. Was on lantus
   70units at NH.
   - hold long acting insulin for now, cover with humalog sliding scale
   .
   # Right Breast Mass and skin changes - concerning for inflammatory
   breast ca vs breast CA relapse. Did have right cyst on [**Last Name (un) **] from [**5-13**]
   with plan for 6 month f/u given comorbidities
   - once stable obtain diagnostic mammography
   .
   # Abdominal Distention
 Ab US w/ evidence of ascites likely related to
   HF in the absence of transaminitis.
   - Monitor for worsening.
   .
   # Delirium on dementia/Depression/Anxiety: Pt with significant
   sundowning last night.  Delirium likely toxic metabolic, infectious.
   Does have intermittent SI. CT head w/o acute process
   - Continue antibiotics for pna
   - Haldol PRN
   - Daily EKGs to monitor QTc
   - Cont increased olanzapine 5mg PO BID
   - Holding ativan and avoiding benzos/anticholinergics
    .
   # Hypertension:
   - cont dilt
   - hold Lisinopril given ARF
   - cont asa
   # ARF: likely from intravascular volume depletion from lasix. Also
   received contrast for CTA
   - Hold lasix

   - mucomyst

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of COPD, lung cancer, and breast cancer, who is currently in the ICU with altered mental status, new hypercarbic/hypoxic respiratory failure, and several other comorbidities.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6C, heart rate of 104 bpm, and blood pressure of 123/98 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation is 82% on a nasal cannula.

The patient has been experiencing increasing oxygen requirements, with an FIO2 of 70% at 06:11 PM. She was given 40mg of IV lasix, which reduced her oxygen requirement to 4L. The goal is to maintain an oxygen saturation of 90-92%.

The patient has been experiencing abdominal pain, which improved with a bowel movement. She has also been having diarrhea overnight and has been ordered to have a stool test for C. diff.

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count. Her electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with elevated sodium, potassium, and chloride levels.

The patient's medications include vancomycin, cefepime, heparin sodium, haloperidol, morphine sulfate, and olanzapine. She has also been receiving IV fluids and diuretics.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Hypercarbic/hypoxic respiratory failure: Hold diuresis, continue nebs, and continue antibiotics for 8 days.
* CHF: Hold ace-I, continue statin, and hold further diuresis with lasix.
* Hypoglycemia/Type II DM: Hold long-acting insulin for now, cover with humalog sliding scale.
* Right breast mass and skin changes: Obtain diagnostic mammography once stable.
* Abdominal distention: Monitor for worsening.
* Delirium: Continue antibiotics for PNA, haldol PRN, daily EKGs to monitor QTc, and continue increased olanzapine 5mg PO BID.
* Hypertension: Continue dilt, hold Lisinopril given ARF, and continue asa.
* ARF: Hold lasix, IVFs, and mucomyst.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's hypercarbic/hypoxic respiratory failure can worsen and lead to respiratory arrest if not managed properly.
* Cardiac failure: The patient's CHF can worsen and lead to cardiac arrest if not managed properly.
* Infection: The patient's altered mental status and new hypercarbic/hypoxic respiratory failure can increase her risk of developing an infection.
* Hypoglycemia: The patient's hypoglycemia can worsen and lead to severe complications if not managed properly.
* Breast cancer recurrence: The patient's right breast mass and skin changes can be a sign of breast cancer recurrence, which requires prompt evaluation and treatment.
* Abdominal distention: The patient's abdominal distention can worsen and lead to complications such as bowel obstruction or perforation if not managed properly.
* Delirium: The patient's delirium can worsen and lead to complications such as falls, aspiration, or respiratory failure if not managed properly.
* Hypertension: The patient's hypertension can worsen and lead to complications such as cardiac failure, stroke, or kidney damage if not managed properly.
* ARF: The patient's ARF can worsen and lead to complications such as cardiac failure, respiratory failure, or death if not managed properly.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.6C, heart rate of 104 bpm, blood pressure of 123/98 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 29 inspirations per minute. The patient's lab results show a white blood cell count of 9.2-10.9 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.8 g/dL, platelet count of 218 K/uL, and creatinine of 1.1-1.4 mg/dL. The patient's troponin-T level is 0.09 ng/mL, and their lactate level is 0.6 mmol/L.

The patient has been experiencing diarrhea and has been ordered stool for C. diff. The patient's abdomen is tender, and they have been experiencing abdominal pain.

The patient's medical history is significant for breast cancer, and they have been treated with vancomycin and cefipime.

5. Cardiac complications: The patient's troponin-T level is elevated, and they may be at risk for cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Infection: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and they may be at risk for infection.
7. Delirium: The patient's delirium and confusion may be a sign of a underlying condition, such as infection, sepsis, or metabolic disturbance.
8. DVT: The patient's risk for DVT is increased due to their immobility and underlying medical conditions.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's oxygen requirements and adjust therapy as necessary.
2. Monitor the patient's temperature and blood pressure and adjust therapy as necessary.

4. Consider ordering additional labs, such as a complete metabolic panel and a blood culture, to evaluate the patient's electrolyte levels and rule out infection.

6. Continue to monitor the patient's abdomen and consider ordering additional imaging studies, such as a CT scan, to evaluate the patient's abdominal pain.
7. Consider ordering additional medications, such as antibiotics or antifungals, to treat the patient's underlying medical conditions.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and consider ordering additional medications, such as antidepressants or antipsychotics, to treat the patient's depression and delirium.

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of COPD, lung cancer, and breast cancer. She is currently in the ICU with acute hypercarbic/hypoxic respiratory failure, likely due to acute on chronic heart failure and COPD exacerbation. She has been treated with Lasix, vancomycin, and cefepime for empiric coverage of hospital-acquired pneumonia. She also has delirium, depression, and anxiety, and has been treated with Haldol and olanzapine. She has developed acute kidney injury, likely due to intravascular volume depletion from Lasix and contrast for CTA. She has also developed hypernatremia, urethral trauma, and hypoglycemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to her underlying COPD and heart failure, and may require more aggressive treatment such as mechanical ventilation.
2. Infectious complications: The patient is at risk for developing infectious complications, such as pneumonia or sepsis, due to her immunocompromised state and the presence of central lines and Foley catheters.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's heart failure may worsen due to her underlying conditions, and may require more aggressive treatment such as inotropes or mechanical circulatory support.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's delirium and depression may worsen due to her underlying conditions, and may require more aggressive treatment such as antipsychotics or antidepressants.
5. Renal complications: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen due to her underlying conditions, and may require more aggressive treatment such as dialysis.
6. Urological complications: The patient's urethral trauma may worsen due to her underlying conditions, and may require more aggressive treatment such as antibiotics or urological intervention.
7. Endocrine complications: The patient's hypoglycemia may worsen due to her underlying conditions, and may require more aggressive treatment such as insulin therapy.
8. Nutritional complications: The patient's nutritional status may worsen due to her underlying conditions, and may require more aggressive treatment such as enteral nutrition or parenteral nutrition.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress as follows:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), lung cancer, and breast cancer. She was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, hypercarbic/hypoxic respiratory failure, and suspected infectious process.

Over the past 24 hours, the patient's oxygen requirement increased to 70% FIO2, and she was given 40mg IV lasix, which reduced her oxygen requirement to 4L. She also experienced abdominal pain, which improved with bowel movement, and has been having diarrhea overnight.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.6C (97.9F)
* Heart rate: 104 bpm (89-109 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 123/98 mmHg (104-143/98 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 29 breaths per minute (20-34 breaths per minute)
* SpO2: 82%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 9.2-10.9 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 33.0-33.5%
* Platelet count: 220-218 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.1-1.2 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.09 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 0.6 mmol/L
* Calcium: 9.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.8 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:

* Hypercarbic/hypoxic respiratory failure
* Acute on chronic heart failure
* Pulmonary hypertension
* Infectious process (suspected)
* Hypertension
* Hypoglycemia (type II diabetes)
* Right breast mass and skin changes (concerning for inflammatory breast cancer or breast cancer relapse)
* Abdominal distension (likely related to heart failure)
* Delirium (toxic metabolic, infectious)
* Depression
* Anxiety

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Sepsis
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Worsening of hypertension
* Hypoglycemic events
* Inflammatory breast cancer or breast cancer relapse
* Abdominal compartment syndrome
* Urethral trauma (from repeated removal of foley catheter)

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing antibiotics for pneumonia
* Monitoring for worsening respiratory failure
* Weaning oxygen therapy
* Holding lasix and IV fluids
* Managing hypertension and hypoglycemia
* Monitoring for signs of infection and sepsis
* Obtaining diagnostic mammography for right breast mass and skin changes
* Continuing antidepressant and antipsychotic medications
* Holding ativan and avoiding benzodiazepines and anticholinergics.

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of diabetes, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and right-sided lung cancer who was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress, hyperacute pneumonia, and volume overload. She is currently on vancomycin and cefipime for pneumonia and is being treated with atrovent nebs and oxygen therapy. Her acute renal failure is likely related to aggressive diuresis, and she is being considered for a fluid trial. She is also experiencing worsening respiratory distress with oxygen requirements up to 70% FiO2, and a CXR has been ordered to evaluate for pulmonary edema or aspiration.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's worsening respiratory distress and oxygen requirements could be indicative of pulmonary edema, which could worsen her respiratory status and increase her risk of cardiac arrest.
2. Aspiration: The patient's recent fluid bolus and worsening respiratory distress could increase her risk of aspiration, which could lead to pneumonia, respiratory failure, and cardiac arrest.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's ongoing diuresis and potential fluid trial could worsen her AKI, leading to further renal dysfunction and increased risk of cardiovascular events.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's underlying COPD and CHF could increase her risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
5. Delirium and Depression: The patient's recent hospitalization and underlying dementia could increase her risk of delirium and depression, which could worsen her mental status and increase her risk of falls and other complications.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia could worsen her electrolyte imbalance and increase her risk of seizures, cardiac arrhythmias, and other complications.
7. Infection: The patient's ongoing pneumonia and potential aspiration could increase her risk of infection, which could lead to further respiratory failure, sepsis, and cardiovascular events.

   78 yo F with h/o COPD, lung ca s/p lobectomy, breast CA s/p lumpectomy
   who presents with altered mental status and new hypercarbic/hypoxic
   respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic/Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Most likely [**1-6**] acute on
   chronic heart failure, with concominent COPD exacerbation (at baseline
   patient is a CO2 retainer). CXR w/ opacities and leukocytosis on
   admission, also suspicion for infectious process.  No evidence of PE on
   CTA.
   - Overall, I recommend a change in the focus of her care from
   life-prolonging to quality improving. I do not suspect her hypoxia can
   improve significantly and may be close to her basline, but we can try
   to treat her dyspnea symptoms.
   - Continue Lasix gtt if IV access allowed
   - Standing short-acting nebs
   - Cont vanc/cefepime for empiric coverage of HCAP for 8 day course
   (start date [**2189-1-23**])
   - Wean O2 (on 2L nc at home)
   - [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Strict I
s, needs foley
   - Morphine for dyspnea
   - Would prefer to call pt out to floor under the geriatric service,
   then to an extended care facility
   .
   # CHF: Acute on chronic diastolic CHF. Echo w/ RHF and pulm HTN, and
   evidence of ascites on abdominal US.
   - holding ace-I given elevated Cr
   - continue statin
   - lasix gtt
   - Strict I
   .
   # Delirium on dementia/Depression/Anxiety: Improved for time being. Pt
   with significant sundowning.  Delirium likely toxic metabolic,
   infectious over chronic dementia. Does have intermittent SI. CT head
   w/o acute process. Appreciate psych recs greatly. Unfortunately, pt can
   become occasionally belligerent, agitated and has not responded to
   zyprexa 5mg prn x 2, nor to haldol 2mg x 2, therefore would prefer
   using higher doses during acute episodes with daily QTC monitoring.
   - Continue antibiotics for pna

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of COPD, lung cancer, and breast cancer, who was admitted to the MICU with respiratory distress and hypoxia. She has been diagnosed with acute on chronic heart failure, COPD exacerbation, and possible infectious process. The patient has been treated with Lasix, albuterol, and ipratropium nebs, and has been started on empiric antibiotics for HCAP. She has also been treated for delirium, depression, and anxiety.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is tenuous, and she is at risk of further respiratory failure.
2. Infection: The patient has a possible infectious process, and the antibiotics started may not be effective against the underlying infection.
3. Heart Failure: The patient has acute on chronic heart failure, and her condition may deteriorate further.
4. Delirium: The patient has delirium, which may worsen her overall condition and increase her risk of complications.
5. Urethral Trauma: The patient has had multiple foley catheter removals, which may have caused urethral trauma.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia has resolved, but she is at risk of developing hypernatremia again if her sodium levels are not carefully monitored.
7. Hypoglycemia: The patient has had hypoglycemia, and her glucose levels may fluctuate if her insulin regimen is not carefully managed.
8. Hypertension: The patient has hypertension, which may worsen her cardiovascular condition.
9. Right Breast Mass: The patient has a right breast mass, which may be a sign of inflammatory breast cancer or breast cancer relapse.
10. Fluid Overload: The patient has fluid overload, which may worsen her respiratory and cardiovascular status.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is critical, and her treatment plan should focus on managing her respiratory status, infection, and heart failure. She should be closely monitored for signs of infection, and her antibiotics should be adjusted accordingly. Her delirium should be managed with antipsychotics and benzodiazepines as needed. Her urethral trauma should be managed with a foley catheter and careful monitoring of her I/Os. Her hypernatremia and hypoglycemia should be closely monitored, and her insulin regimen should be adjusted accordingly. Her hypertension should be managed with antihypertensive medications, and her right breast mass should be evaluated further with diagnostic mammography.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-inch tall individual with a current weight of 77.3 kg, admitted to the MICU with respiratory distress due to hypoxia and tachypnea.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3C (97.4F), heart rate of 100 bpm, and blood pressure of 114/60 mmHg. The patient's respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 97%.

The patient has a history of cancer, depression, and hypertension. The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 9.2-10.9 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 33.0-36.5 g/dL, and platelet count of 220-242 x 10^9/L.

The patient's imaging results show a small right-sided pleural effusion with local atelectasis at the right lung base, and the cardiac silhouette is moderately enlarged.

The patient has been treated with albuterol and ipratropium nebs, Lasix 60mg bolus and drip, olanzapine, haloperidol, and quetiapine. The patient has also received antibiotics, including vancomycin and cefipime.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the provided information include:

1. Respiratory failure due to hypoxia and tachypnea.
2. Sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's positive urine culture and potential bacterial infection.
3. Pneumonia or pleurisy due to the small right-sided pleural effusion and local atelectasis.
4. Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia due to the patient's glycemic control and potential insulin resistance.
5. DVT or stress ulcer due to the patient's immobility and potential bleeding risk.
6. VAP or pneumonia due to the patient's respiratory support and potential bacterial colonization.
7. Delirium or depression due to the patient's underlying medical conditions and potential medication side effects.
8. Hypertension or hypotension due to the patient's underlying medical conditions and potential medication side effects.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies to identify any potential complications and adjust treatment accordingly.

   78 yo F with h/o COPD, lung ca s/p lobectomy, breast CA s/p lumpectomy
   who presents with altered mental status and new hypercarbic/hypoxic
   respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic/Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Most likely [**1-6**] acute on
   chronic heart failure, with concominent COPD exacerbation (at baseline
   patient is a CO2 retainer). CXR w/ opacities and leukocytosis on
   admission, also suspicion for infectious process.  Echo also notable
   for moderate pulmonary hypertension with RHF/LHF.  No evidence of PE on
   CTA. Overall, I recommend a change in the focus of her care from
   life-prolonging to quality improving. I do not suspect her hypoxia can
   improve significantly and may be close to her basline, but we can try
   to treat her dyspnea symptoms.
   - Continue Lasix gtt if IV access allowed
   - Standing short-acting nebs
   - Cont vanc/cefepime for empiric coverage of HCAP for 8 day course
   (start date [**2189-1-23**])
   - Wean O2 (on 2L nc at home)
   - [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Strict I
s, needs foley
   - Morphine for dyspnea
   - Would prefer to call pt out to floor with [**Female First Name (un) **] consult
   .
   # CHF: Acute on chronic diastolic CHF. Echo w/ RHF and pulm HTN, and
   evidence of ascites on abdominal US.
   - holding ace-I given elevated Cr
   - continue statin
   - lasix gtt
   - Strict I
   .
   # Delirium on dementia/Depression/Anxiety: Improved for time being. Pt
   with significant sundowning.  Delirium likely toxic metabolic,
   infectious over chronic dementia. Does have intermittent SI. CT head
   w/o acute process
   - Continue antibiotics for pna
   - Haldol PRN
   - Daily EKGs to monitor QTc
   - Cont increased olanzapine 5mg PO BID
   - Holding ativan and avoiding benzos/anticholinergics
   - Continue restraints
   - Discuss w/ psych re: further management
    .
   # ARF: likely from intravascular volume depletion from lasix. Also
   received contrast for CTA
   - Hold lasix
   - IVFs
   - mucomyst
   # Hypernatremia: Free water defecit ~1.7L
   - D5W at 130cc/hr for 1.5 L, with PM lytes
   # Urethral trauma s/p several removals of foley with balloon inflation
   - Consider urology consult, concern for foley related trauma
   .
   # Hypoglycemia/Type II DM with complications
 Improved. Was on lantus
   70units at NH.
   - hold long acting insulin for now, cover with humalog sliding scale
   - can likely restart lantus after acute process
   .
   # Hypertension:
   - cont dilt
   - hold Lisinopril given ARF
   - cont asa
   .
   # Right Breast Mass and skin changes - concerning for inflammatory
   breast ca vs breast CA relapse. Did have right cyst on [**Last Name (un) **] from [**5-13**]
   with plan for 6 month f/u given comorbidities
   - once stable obtain diagnostic mammography
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Cardiac healthy
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2189-1-26**] 03:31 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: HSC
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: DNR / DNI
   Disposition: ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of COPD, lung cancer, and breast cancer who was admitted to the MICU with respiratory distress, altered mental status, and new hypercarbic/hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient's condition is complicated by acute on chronic heart failure, concomitant COPD exacerbation, and suspicion of an infectious process. The patient's focus of care has been changed from life-prolonging to quality improving, and the goal is to manage symptoms and improve the patient's quality of life.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to continue, and the patient may require ongoing respiratory support.
2. Infection: The patient's suspicion of an infectious process, such as pneumonia, may lead to further complications, including sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Heart failure: The patient's acute on chronic heart failure may worsen, leading to further cardiac compromise and potential cardiogenic shock.
4. Delirium: The patient's delirium may continue to be a concern, and the patient may require ongoing management with medications such as haloperidol and olanzapine.
5. Urethral trauma: The patient's repeated removal of the Foley catheter with balloon inflation may have caused urethral trauma, which could lead to further complications, including bleeding and infection.
6. Hypoglycemia: The patient's hypoglycemia may recur, particularly if the patient's long-acting insulin is not restarted or if the patient's oral medications are not adjusted.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may worsen if the patient's free water deficit is not addressed.
8. Right breast mass: The patient's right breast mass may be a sign of inflammatory breast cancer or breast cancer relapse, which requires further evaluation and management.
9. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiovascular status is complex, and the patient may be at risk for further cardiovascular complications, including cardiac arrhythmias and cardiogenic shock.
10. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is also complex, and the patient may be at risk for further neurological complications, including seizures and stroke.

   78 yo F with h/o COPD, lung ca s/p lobectomy, breast CA s/p lumpectomy
   who presents with altered mental status and new hypercarbic/hypoxic
   respiratory failure.

   # Hypercarbic/Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Most likely [**1-6**] acute on
   chronic heart failure, with concominent COPD exacerbation (at baseline
   patient is a CO2 retainer). CXR w/ opacities and leukocytosis on
   admission, also suspicion for infectious process.  No evidence of PE on
   CTA.
   - Overall, I recommend a change in the focus of her care from
   life-prolonging to quality improving. I do not suspect her hypoxia can
   improve significantly and may be close to her basline, but we can try
   to treat her dyspnea symptoms.
   - Continue Lasix gtt if IV access allowed
   - Standing short-acting nebs
   - Cont vanc/cefepime for empiric coverage of HCAP for 8 day course

   - [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Strict I
s, needs foley

   - Would prefer to call pt out to floor under the geriatric service,
   then to an extended care facility
   .
   # CHF: Acute on chronic diastolic CHF. Echo w/ RHF and pulm HTN, and
   evidence of ascites on abdominal US.
   - holding ace-I given elevated Cr
   - continue statin
   - lasix gtt
   - Strict I
   .
   # Delirium on dementia/Depression/Anxiety: Improved for time being. Pt
   with significant sundowning.  Delirium likely toxic metabolic,
   infectious over chronic dementia. Does have intermittent SI. CT head
   w/o acute process. Appreciate psych recs greatly. Unfortunately, pt can
   become occasionally belligerent, agitated and has not responded to
   zyprexa 5mg prn x 2, nor to haldol 2mg x 2, therefore would prefer
   using higher doses during acute episodes with daily QTC monitoring.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, lung cancer, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). She was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with acute respiratory distress, hypoxia, and tachypnea. The patient has a history of heart failure, hypertension, and type II diabetes with complications. She is currently receiving treatment for hypercarbic/hypoxic respiratory failure, acute on chronic heart failure, and possible infectious process.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Pneumonia:** The patient's CXR shows opacities, and she has leukocytosis, which may indicate a possible pneumonia.
2. **Infectious process:** The patient is receiving empiric antibiotics for a suspected infectious process, which may lead to antibiotic-resistant infections or allergic reactions.
3. **Acute kidney injury (AKI):** The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and she is receiving Lasix, which may worsen AKI.
4. **Hyperglycemia:** The patient's blood glucose levels are elevated, and she is receiving humalog sliding scale insulin, which may lead to hypoglycemia if not monitored closely.
5. **Hypotension:** The patient's blood pressure is low, which may indicate hypovolemic shock or cardiac dysfunction.
6. **Pulmonary edema:** The patient's CXR shows opacities, which may indicate pulmonary edema, a potential complication of heart failure.
7. **Right breast mass and skin changes:** The patient has a right breast mass and skin changes, which may indicate inflammatory breast cancer or breast cancer relapse.
8. **DVT and PE:** The patient is at risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE) due to her immobilization and medical conditions.
9. **VAP:** The patient is at risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to her prolonged mechanical ventilation.
10. **Delirium and agitation:** The patient is experiencing delirium and agitation, which may worsen if not managed properly.

**Recommendations:**

1. Monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely to detect any changes in her condition.
2. Continue antibiotics for the suspected infectious process and monitor for signs of antibiotic resistance.
3. Adjust the patient's insulin regimen to maintain tight glycemic control and prevent hypoglycemia.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust her medication regimen as necessary to prevent cardiac complications.
5. Consider obtaining a diagnostic mammography to evaluate the right breast mass and skin changes.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation as necessary to prevent respiratory complications.
7. Consider placing the patient on anticoagulation therapy to prevent DVT and PE.
8. Monitor the patient's delirium and agitation and adjust her medication regimen as necessary to manage these symptoms.

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, lung cancer, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). She was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with respiratory distress, hypoxia, and tachypnea. The patient's condition is complex, with multiple comorbidities and potential medical complications.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is receiving oxygen therapy and has a SpO2 of 94%. She has a history of COPD and is a CO2 retainer.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has acute on chronic diastolic heart failure (CHF) with evidence of right heart failure and pulmonary hypertension. She is likely intravascularly dry but extravascularly wet.
* Neurological: The patient is somnolent and has a history of depression, dementia, and anxiety. She is at risk for delirium and has had episodes of agitation and aggression.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury (ARF) likely due to intravascular volume depletion from lasix and contrast exposure.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a history of constipation and has been treated with lasix, which has not been effective.
* Infectious: The patient has a positive Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) test and is being treated with intravenous flagyl.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and she may require mechanical ventilation.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient's CHF and ARF increase her risk of cardiac arrest.
* Sepsis: The patient's C. diff infection and other comorbidities increase her risk of developing sepsis.
* Delirium: The patient's neurological condition and medication regimen increase her risk of developing delirium.
* Wound complications: The patient's skin changes and right breast mass may increase her risk of developing wound complications.
* Hypoglycemia: The patient's history of type 2 diabetes and medication regimen increase her risk of developing hypoglycemia.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's history of hypernatremia and medication regimen increase her risk of developing hypernatremia.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing antibiotics for pneumonia
* Monitoring mental status and adjusting medication regimen as needed
* Holding lasix and allowing the patient to reequilibrate on her own
* Continuing olanzapine for depression and anxiety
* Holding ativan and avoiding benzodiazepines and anticholinergics
* Continuing restraints for safety
* Transferring the patient to a rehabilitation facility with a plan for no rehospitalization.

   78 yo F with h/o COPD, lung ca s/p lobectomy, breast CA s/p lumpectomy
   who presents with altered mental status and new hypercarbic/hypoxic
   respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic/Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Most likely [**1-6**] PNA, with
   concominent CHF and COPD exacerbation (at baseline patient is a CO2
   retainer). Is probably intravascularly dry but extravascularly wet. No
   evidence of PE on CTA.
   - No escalation of care per HCP
   - Repeat BNP
   - Hold on lasix boluses given hypotension and ARF
   - Transition to PO lasix if possible
   - Standing short-acting nebs
   - Cont vanc/cefepime for empiric coverage of HCAP for 8 day course
   (start date [**2189-1-23**] until [**2189-1-31**])
   - Wean O2 (on 2L nc at home)
   - Strict I
s, but without foley will have to rely on daily weights
   - Morphine for dyspnea
   - Appreciate geriatrics recommendations
   - Would prefer to call pt out to [**Hospital **] [**Hospital **] Rehab
   # Unresponsiveness: Ruled out hypercarbia. Possibly secondary to being
   hard of hearing and a deep sleeper. Consider volitional
   unresponsiveness. TSH wnl.
   - Monitor mental status
   .
   # CHF: Acute on chronic diastolic CHF. Echo w/ RHF and pulm HTN, and
   evidence of ascites on abdominal US. Pt is probably intravascularly dry
   but extravascularly wet.
   - holding ace-I given elevated Cr
   - continue statin
   - Transition to PO lasix
   - Strict I
s, daily weights
   .
   # Delirium on dementia/Depression/Anxiety: Improved for time being. Pt
   with significant sundowning.  Delirium likely toxic metabolic,
   infectious over chronic dementia. Does have intermittent SI. CT head
   w/o acute process. Unfortunately, pt can become occasionally
   belligerent, agitated and has not responded to zyprexa 5mg prn x 2, nor
   to haldol 2mg x 2, therefore would prefer using higher doses during
   acute episodes with daily QTC monitoring.
   - Continue antibiotics for pna
   - Daily EKGs to monitor QTc
   - Change olanzapine to 2.5mg PO TID per psych recs
   - Holding ativan and avoiding benzos/anticholinergics
   - Removed restraints given calmer symptoms
   - Discuss w/ psych re: further management appreciate their input
    .
   # ARF: likely from intravascular volume depletion from lasix. Also
   received contrast for CTA
   - Hold lasix
   # Hypernatremia: Resolved.
   # Urethral trauma s/p several removals of foley with balloon inflation.
   Has pulled out this foley.
   - No more foley
   .
   # Hypoglycemia/Type II DM with complications
 Improved. Was on lantus
   70units at NH.
   - hold long acting insulin for now, cover with humalog sliding scale
   - can likely restart lantus after acute process
   .
   # Hypertension:
   - cont dilt
   - hold Lisinopril given ARF
   - cont asa
   .
   # Right Breast Mass and skin changes - concerning for inflammatory
   breast ca vs breast CA relapse. Did have right cyst on [**Last Name (un) **] from [**5-13**]
   with plan for 6 month f/u given comorbidities
   - once stable obtain diagnostic mammography
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Cardiac healthy
   Glycemic Control:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, lung cancer, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Her medical history is significant for cardiac enlargement, chronic heart failure, and hypertension.

Current conditions:
